result.execSummary:
The defendant Richard F Nava White was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Possess Drug Paraphernalia, an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 961.573(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Concurrent with: any probation now serving.

miscConds.notes: Paid in full from bond on file.
Obtain and maintain employment, commensurate with his treatment needs.

If agent recommends, defendant must attend and successfully complete an alcohol assessment and comply with any recommended treatment.  Defendant is to execute any releases necessary for agent to verify compliance.

Defendant to be subject to random testing by his agent.

If agent recommends, defendant must attend and successfully complete a drug assessment, and comply with any recommended treatment.  Defendant to execute any releases necessary for agent to verify compliance.

Defendant to be subject to random testing by his agent.

Not to possess or consume any controlled substances.   Not to possess any drug paraphernalia.  Not to possess any prescription medications of any kind unless those have been prescribed to the defendant by a physician, and in that case, the defendant shall take such medications only as prescribed.  Defendant shall not alter the form of any prescription prior to, or in conjunction with, ingestion.

Defendant shall have no contact, directly or indirectly, either personally, by mail, telephone or through any other person, or by any other means, with William Hoover.

The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by a risk and needs assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.

Credit for 67 days, if revoked.

Amended Judgment of Conviction After Revocation

records.addlTxt: 15CM181 & 15CM187:  Defendant appears in custody with counsel SPD Carly Sebion.  Gerald Fox appears for the State.  DA Fox stipulates to 154 total days sentence credit to apply to both cases.  DA makes correction to revocation summary of max jail time in 15CM187 only.  DA Fox recommends the max of 9 months jail in 15CM181 and 15CM187 to run concurrent with that case.  SPD Sebion recommends 6 months on obstructing (15CM181) and 30 days concurrent on possession of paraphernalia (15CM187).  Sebion notes he owes a total of approximately $237 on these two cases.  Defendant does not excercise his right to allocution.  Court orders on 15CM181 a 6 month jail term with credit for 154 days served; 15CM187- 30 days jail concurrent to 15CM181 - deemed time served.  Imposes on 15CM181 - $237.48 civil judgment unless there is a different amount since the revocation summary was submitted.

ADA Melissa Inlow appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in person, in custody, with Attorney Grams.  Defendant plead guilty to Poss of drug para in 15CM187 and  Obstruction in 15CM181.  Other charges dismissed, but read in for sentencing purposes.  Joint recommendation for 18 mo. probation.  Court recited the charges and possible penalties on the counts he plead to.   Defendant understood.  Court reviewed the plea questionnaire, constitutional rights and elements with the defendant.  Defense stipulated that there is a factual basis for the plea.   Court found that the defendant freely, voluntarily, and intelligently entered his pleas and waived his constitutional rights.  Court found that a factual basis exists for the pleas.  Found guilty of Possession of drug paraphernalia and Obstructing.  Joint recommendation for 18 months probation.  Concurrent.    The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by a risk and needs assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.  AODA and recommended treatment.  o/m employment. Defendant shall not alter the form of any prescription prior to, or in conjunction with, ingestion.
